description:
## Objective
This job will change the owner of a job to a different user. This is done using RBA API by exporting and importing the job definition without any changes. 

It will then change the job owner to the user account associated to the token used for export/import.

This can be helpful when you want to use a specific local account to manage all job schedules. This will avoid a job schedule to become orphan when a user is removed from RBA.

## Requirements
- Python installed
- User RBA API Token available in the Key Storage under path: `keys/users/[USERNAME]/rba-api-token`
    - If you're following a different naming convention, edit the job and change the option `user-account-token` default value.

## How to use this
1. Make sure you have your users RBA API tokens created under the path `keys/users/[USERNAME]/rba-api-token` or other path convention defined in job option `user-account-token`.
2. Run the job with option values:
    1. Job ID: ID of the job to get a new owner
    2. User Account: Username of the new owner of the jobs
name: Job Scheduler

options.description: Rundeck user account to schedule the job
options.label: User Account
options.name: user-account

commands.script:
import requests

# Define the server, job UUID, and API token
server = 'bdias.pd-sandbox.com'
jobUUID = '@option.job-id@'
api_token = '@option.user-account-api-token@'

# Step 1: Perform the GET request to fetch the JSON response
get_url = f'https://{server}/api/48/project/dev/jobs/export?format=json&idlist={jobUUID}'
get_headers = {
    'Accept': 'application/json',
    'X-Rundeck-Auth-Token': api_token
}

response = requests.get(get_url, headers=get_headers)

# Check if the GET request was successful
if response.status_code == 200:
    json_response = response.json()  # Save the JSON response as a variable
    print("GET request successful. JSON response saved.")
else:
    print(f"GET request failed with status code {response.status_code}")
    print(response.text)
    exit(1)

# Step 2: Use the saved JSON response as the payload in a POST request
post_url = f'https://{server}/api/48/project/dev/jobs/import?fileformat=json&dupeOption=update'
post_headers = {
    'Accept': 'application/json',
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'X-Rundeck-Auth-Token': api_token
}

# Perform the POST request
post_response = requests.post(post_url, json=json_response, headers=post_headers)

# Check if the POST request was successful
if post_response.status_code == 200:
    print("POST request successful.")
    print(post_response.json())  # Print the response from the server
else:
    print(f"POST request failed with status code {post_response.status_code}")
    print(post_response.text)
